review.title: Properties of ABA+ for Non-Monotonic Reasoning: Errata
review.abstract: We investigate properties of ABA+, a formalism that extends the well studied structured argumentation formalism Assumption-Based Argumentation (ABA) with a preference handling mechanism. In particular, we establish desirable properties that ABA+ semantics exhibit. These pave way to the satisfaction by ABA+ of some (arguably) desirable principles of preference handling in argumentation and non-monotonic reasoning, as well as non-monotonic inference properties of ABA+ under various semantics.

sections.text: Referring to (Amgoud and Vesic 2009), in (Brewka, Truszczyn ́ ski and Woltran 2010), the authors have pointed out two (probably) desirable properties of argumentation formalisms dealing with preferences, namely conflict maintenance and the absence of preferences. sections.heading: 7 Related and Future Work
sections.text: The principles of the Contraposition of (strict) rules (see e.g. (Caminada and Amgoud 2007; Modgil and Prakken 2013) are mainly applied in the well-studied structured argumentation formalisms ASPIC + (Modgil and Prakken 2013).The principle as such can also be found in the classic logic-based approaches to structured reasoning such as (Gorogiannis and Hunter 2011).Similar to ASPIC +, ABA + uses Contraposition to ensure the fundamental properties of Lemma (cf.), argues Lemma 3).As a consequence, Contraposition paves way to satisfaction of desirable properties of ABA + semantics, as well as Preference handling and non-monotonic properties in Sections 5 and 6. sections.heading: 8 Conclusions
sections.text: We examined various properties of a recently proposed non-monotonous argumentation formalism ABA + (Cayras and Toni 2016), which deals with preferences in structured reasoning. In particular, we first found that ABA +, assuming the principle of counterposition (see e.g. (Modgil und Prakken 2013), exhibits desirable properties similar to those of other existing argumentation formalisms, such as (Dung 1995). Then we showed that ABA + fulfils some (well) desirable principles of preferential treatment in reasoning and non-monotonous thinking, e.g. (Brewka and Eiter 1999). Finally, we analyzed non-monotonous consequential properties (as in (Cayras and Toni 2015)) of ABA + under various semantics. We believe that our work contributes to the understanding of preferences within reasoning in particular and in non-monotonous thinking overall.
